item.title: GPT-5 Coding Playbook: Obedient, Capable—Without Overkill
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

This generation of GPT-5 is noticeably more “well-behaved.” It follows instructions better, plans better, and is more willing to look things up and take action. There’s a catch, though: the vaguer you are, the more it tends to “overdo it.”

Here’s how to turn GPT-5 into a reliable coding partner with minimal words: it follows your rules, moves at your cadence, and avoids detours. These points come from OpenAI’s official memos and guides — distilled for you.

Main Content

Section titled “Main Content”

1) Say It Clearly First: Don’t Give Conflicting Rules

Section titled “1) Say It Clearly First: Don’t Give Conflicting Rules”

GPT-5 is stronger at instruction-following, but it’s sensitive to conflicting requirements. If your .cursor/rules or AGENTS.md says A while your prompt says the opposite B, the model will hesitate and serve neither well. Action: unify your “project rules,” say one thing per sentence, don’t shout multiple slogans at once.

Tip: keep “team conventions” in one file, and inject the same block of “rules” into every session.

2) Choose the Right “Thinking Intensity”: Hard → High, Easy → Lower

Section titled “2) Choose the Right “Thinking Intensity”: Hard → High, Easy → Lower”

GPT-5 reasons by default, but you can tune reasoning_effort. Go high for difficult tasks and medium/low for routine ones to avoid overkill and excessive tool calls. The official guide also introduces minimal reasoning for speed-sensitive cases.

Heuristics:

  • Multi-file or cross-module refactors → high.
  • Minor style tweaks or simple scripts → medium or low.

3) Use “XML-Style” Prompts to Modularize Rules

Section titled “3) Use “XML-Style” Prompts to Modularize Rules”

GPT-5 responds well to structured prompts. Use XML-like blocks to separate principles, default stacks, and directory conventions. You’ll get more stability and consistency.

Ready to copy:

4) Avoid Overly Forceful Tone

Section titled “4) Avoid Overly Forceful Tone”

“You must be exhaustive” or “collect all information first before answering” can backfire with GPT-5: it may over-gather context and overuse tools — slow and costly. Relax the tone and set boundaries instead.

5) Give It Time to “Think Before Writing”

Section titled “5) Give It Time to “Think Before Writing””

When building something from scratch, add a short self-planning and self-check loop. Quality becomes noticeably more stable. Ask the model to define a rubric first and then iterate until it meets the rubric.

Template snippet:

6) Tame “Over-Eagerness”: Set Tool Budgets and Reporting Cadence

Section titled “6) Tame “Over-Eagerness”: Set Tool Budgets and Reporting Cadence”

GPT-5 is proactive and tries to gather as much context as possible. In your prompt, define the “eagerness level”:

  • When to search in parallel
  • Max tool-call budget
  • When to report progress to humans

Two ready-made styles:

  • Time-saving conservative (low eagerness/low budget)
  • Full exploration (high eagerness/high persistence)

Also enable tool preambles so the model narrates plan and progress while working — much better UX.

7) Environment and Engineering Considerations

Section titled “7) Environment and Engineering Considerations”
  • IDE partner: use OpenAI’s Codex IDE extension with GPT-5 to read/modify/run files inline and pair on tasks. Official references include AGENTS.md patterns.
  • Responses API: when chaining multiple tool calls, reuse prior reasoning context for better speed and cost. In production, orchestrate with the Responses API.
  • Parameter baseline: default to medium within cost constraints; raise to high for complex refactors; try minimal when latency-sensitive.

8) Team “Single Source of Truth” Checklist (Drop into Your Repo)

Section titled “8) Team “Single Source of Truth” Checklist (Drop into Your Repo)”

Use together with <code_editing_rules> from section 3 to pull GPT-5’s output toward team-level consistency.

Closing

Section titled “Closing”

In one line: unify rules, tier your reasoning, and control the process. Do these three well and GPT-5 will ship in your codebase fast and steady — without “smart but self-defeating” behavior. Calibrate with the official memos/guides and tune to your team’s style.

item.title: Don’t want Claude Code to feed your code to Anthropic? Use this privacy settings checklist
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR: For personal accounts (Free/Pro/Max), go to claude.ai → Settings → Data & Privacy and turn off “Use my chats/coding sessions to improve the model.” For organizations/API, usage is not used for training by default; for extra assurance, use Zero Data Retention (ZDR) with an org API key for Claude Code. On your machine, disable Statsig telemetry/Sentry error reporting, don’t use /bug to upload sessions, and periodically clear local caches.

Why lock it down now

Section titled “Why lock it down now”

Anthropic is updating data policy for consumer products (including Claude, Pro, Max, and Claude Code when signed in with those accounts): you can choose whether chats and coding sessions are used for training; if you choose Allow, the retention period can be up to 5 years. If you choose Do not allow, the service side retains up to 30 days for operations and compliance. This choice only applies to newly created or “resumed” sessions (no retroactive scanning of dormant history). You can change it anytime in Privacy Settings.

For industry coverage and reminders about timing, see summaries from The Verge / Tom’s Guide.

Safest setups for three user types

Section titled “Safest setups for three user types”

① Personal users (Free / Pro / Max)

Section titled “① Personal users (Free / Pro / Max)”

Goal: prevent your chats and code from being used for training.

How to do it

  1. Open claude.ai → Settings → Data & Privacy.
  2. Turn off “Use my chats/coding sessions to improve Claude” (or similar wording).
  3. Remember: this only applies to new/resumed sessions; deleted conversations will not be used for training. You can change this later, but data already used for training cannot be undone.

Retention rules (when you disable training): backend storage for up to 30 days.

② Team / Enterprise / API (commercial products)

Section titled “② Team / Enterprise / API (commercial products)”

Default is safer: Anthropic’s commercial products (Claude for Work, Anthropic API, Claude Gov, etc.) do not use your inputs/outputs for training by default.

Even safer (recommended): sign Zero Data Retention (ZDR) and use your organization’s API key in Claude Code. ZDR currently applies only to the Anthropic API and products that use your org API key (including Claude Code).

Default retention: on the API side, 30‑day auto‑deletion (if ZDR isn’t in place and absent additional legal/risk requirements).

③ Go via cloud providers (Bedrock / Vertex) for another layer of isolation

Section titled “③ Go via cloud providers (Bedrock / Vertex) for another layer of isolation”
  • AWS Bedrock: explicitly does not use your inputs/outputs to train models; contract terms also constrain third‑party models (including Anthropic).
  • Google Vertex AI: has dedicated data governance and caching docs; enterprises can configure to meet compliance and minimize retention (read caching/governance details carefully).

This “cloud‑side isolation” suits highly regulated sectors, keeping orchestration, logs, and KMS within your cloud account under unified governance.

Local hardening you must do for Claude Code

Section titled “Local hardening you must do for Claude Code”

These are the most commonly overlooked steps in “keep it private” practice; once done, you’ll be much more at ease.

A. Disable telemetry and error reporting (keep runtime metrics local)

Section titled “A. Disable telemetry and error reporting (keep runtime metrics local)”

Officially supported environment variables (cross‑platform example):

You can also write these under the env node in ~/.claude/settings.json, and override per‑project via .claude/settings.local.json.

B. Avoid bundling full sessions for upload (don’t casually use /bug)

Section titled “B. Avoid bundling full sessions for upload (don’t casually use /bug)”
  • The official recommendation is to use /bug to submit issues; it bundles context for Anthropic to diagnose. Therefore avoid it when dealing with sensitive repos/code.
  • The community has collected an env var to disable /bug (DISABLE_BUG_COMMAND=1). This is “unofficial / may change” — for reference only.

C. Local caches and session files

Section titled “C. Local caches and session files”
  • Per official notes, the client can cache sessions locally for up to 30 days to aid resuming (configurable). In sensitive environments, regularly clean ~/.claude/ and set cache duration to a minimum.
  • The community has previously reported issues about .claude.json retaining conversation fragments — these are behavioral reports, not official guarantees. Add .claude/ to your security baseline and backup exclusion lists.

A “belt‑and‑suspenders” playbook (copy as‑is)

Section titled “A “belt‑and‑suspenders” playbook (copy as‑is)”

Personal accounts (must‑do)

  1. Turn off “Use to improve the model.”
  2. Periodically clean ~/.claude/; before using /bug, do redaction/sanitization.
  3. Set: DISABLE_TELEMETRY=1, DISABLE_ERROR_REPORTING=1.

Teams/enterprises (strongly recommended)

  1. Only log into Claude Code with your org API key; sign ZDR if possible.
  2. Inject the “no‑upload” env vars (Section A) centrally across servers and CI/CD.
  3. Prefer Bedrock/Vertex routes; implement cloud‑side DLP/KMS and access auditing.

Common pitfalls to avoid

Section titled “Common pitfalls to avoid”

  • Myth 1: “If I delete historical chats, they won’t be used for training.” → After deletion, they won’t be used for training, but whether they were trained on depends on your setting at the time; training is irreversible.

  • Myth 2: “Using Claude Code equals enterprise‑grade protection.” → It depends on the account and key you use. Claude Code signed in with a personal account is still under consumer terms.

  • Myth 3: “If I go via Bedrock/Vertex, I’m done.” → You still need to configure your own permission boundaries, key management, logging policies, and cache governance. The docs are explicit.

Closing

Section titled “Closing”

Data privacy has never been a simple on/off switch. It’s a set of habits: right configuration + right tools + team discipline. Work through the checklist above and your code and conversations will not be shared with Anthropic for training, while you also preserve your team’s compliance boundary.

item.title: NVIDIA’s P/E Paradox: A Deep Valuation Analysis Behind a Multi‑Trillion Run
item.content:encoded:
NVIDIA’s P/E Paradox: A Deep Valuation Analysis Behind a Multi‑Trillion Run

Section titled “NVIDIA’s P/E Paradox: A Deep Valuation Analysis Behind a Multi‑Trillion Run”

At the peak of the global tech investment wave, NVIDIA stands out as the brightest star. Yet despite a market cap that has crossed $4T, its recent price action has puzzled many investors. The company delivered another quarter above Wall Street expectations, but the stock fell after hours and even flirted with a technical bear market. This “beat but drop” paradox raises a central question: is this an overreaction driven by short‑term sentiment, or the first crack in a grand narrative of overvaluation?

This article uses the price‑to‑earnings ratio (P/E) as the core lens to examine NVIDIA’s value. We look at the latest financials, trace valuation shifts over time, analyze the engines that power long‑term growth and the risks that could slow it, and outline a forward view for the next decade—offering a clear, grounded perspective for everyday investors.

Why did the stock fall after an earnings beat?

Section titled “Why did the stock fall after an earnings beat?”

On the surface, NVIDIA’s latest report was “picture‑perfect.” In FY26 Q2, total revenue reached $46.7B, up 56% year over year. GAAP net income rose 59% to $26.4B. Non‑GAAP diluted EPS came in at $1.05, above the $1.01 consensus. For Q3, management guided revenue of $54.0B, again ahead of Street expectations around $53.1B. The board also approved up to $60B in share repurchases.

So why the sell‑off? The core reason is the “expectations trap.” For a company whose share price nearly tripled over the past year, adding roughly $2T in market value, the market has become conditioned to miracle‑level growth. When expectations are super‑charged, even a small shortfall versus the most optimistic whispers can trigger disappointment.

In particular, investors fixated on the Data Center segment. Although it contributed 88% of total revenue ($41.1B) and grew strongly, it modestly missed the loftiest estimates, which some interpreted as a sign that near‑term growth may be bumping up against a ceiling. And while 56% y/y growth is extraordinary for almost any business, it was also NVIDIA’s slowest growth rate in nine quarters since the AI upcycle began.

When a company’s bar moves from “great” to “mythic,” even strong prints can disappoint. Short‑term price swings here reflect the market’s sensitivity to NVIDIA’s forward growth trajectory.

Below is a summary of key quarterly metrics:

Table 1: NVIDIA FY26 Q2 – Key Financials

MetricActual (USD)Street (USD)Y/YNotes
Total Revenue$46.7B$46.05B56%Beat, but slowest y/y growth in 9 quarters
Data Center Revenue$41.1B$41.3B56%Slight miss versus high bar; drives narrative
Gaming Revenue$4.3B–49%Strong rebound
Robotics/Auto$586M–69%Small base, solid growth
Net Income (GAAP)$26.4B–59%Operating leverage remains strong
Diluted EPS (Non‑GAAP)$1.05$1.0154%Clear beat
Q3 Revenue Guide$54.0B ±2%$53.1B–Beat; excludes H20 shipments to China
Buyback Authorization$60B––Signals confidence; also hints at a new phase

Data: Company filings and market estimates

P/E as the measuring stick: history, reality, and the “overvaluation” debate

Section titled “P/E as the measuring stick: history, reality, and the “overvaluation” debate”

P/E is the simplest yardstick for what investors are willing to pay today for one dollar of a company’s earnings. High‑growth companies command higher P/Es, reflecting expectations for sustained, superior earnings expansion.

NVIDIA’s P/E evolution broadly falls into three phases:

  • Phase 1 (Pre‑AI boom): Before the generative AI surge, NVIDIA traded around 20–60x P/E, supported by strong gaming and cryptocurrency cycles.

  • Phase 2 (AI mania begins): With the rise of large language models and the “picks‑and‑shovels” narrative, NVIDIA’s P/E spiked to an all‑time high—peaking around 139x in April 2023, with some estimates running even higher—capturing the market’s euphoric sentiment.

  • Phase 3 (Back to rationality): Despite the stock’s continued rise thereafter, the P/E multiple steadily compressed—reflecting earnings growth catching up with price. The market shifted from purely “story‑driven” to increasingly “earnings‑driven.”

This transition matters. When growth is both fast and visible, multiples don’t have to be extreme to support strong returns; earnings do more of the heavy lifting as the business scales. NVIDIA’s P/E compression—alongside rising profitability—suggests a maturing narrative: from hype premium to fundamentals premium.

What supports a premium multiple—and what could challenge it

Section titled “What supports a premium multiple—and what could challenge it”

Structural reasons for a premium:

  • Full‑stack moat: From CUDA to networking, systems, and software, NVIDIA’s integrated stack creates high switching costs and developer lock‑in.
  • Platform upgrade cycle: Blackwell ramps as the next‑gen platform while the ecosystem readies for B100/B200 transitions across hyperscalers and enterprises. |- Software attach and platform revenue: Growing monetization via NVIDIA AI Enterprise, Omniverse, and vertical platforms lifts lifetime value beyond silicon.
  • Capital allocation: Large, recurring buybacks signal cash‑flow confidence and discipline.

Key risks that could compress the multiple:

  • Geopolitics: Export controls and supply chain restrictions may cap upside in specific regions or product lines.
  • Competition: AMD (MI series), custom silicon from hyperscalers, and potential vertical integration can pressure share and pricing power.
  • Supply‑demand balance: If AI infrastructure spend normalizes faster than expected, revenue growth and gross margins could decelerate.
  • Valuation risk: If the market concludes that hyper‑growth is not sustainable, multiples can revert quickly.

Long‑term view through the P/E lens

Section titled “Long‑term view through the P/E lens”

Consensus expects NVIDIA’s P/E to continue normalizing as earnings compound: roughly the mid‑40s in FY26, low‑30s in FY27, and mid‑20s by FY28, assuming high double‑digit to strong‑double‑digit earnings growth.

This shift suggests a transition from a company priced mainly on narrative to one anchored in durable profitability—a “tech blue chip.” Investors should expect fewer sudden multiple expansions and more return driven by steady earnings growth.

Ten‑year scenarios

Section titled “Ten‑year scenarios”

— Bull case: A new industrial wave of AI. If NVIDIA defends its CUDA moat, executes the Blackwell roadmap, and AI infrastructure spending becomes a multi‑trillion market, P/E can sustain in the 30–40x range while earnings growth drives continued share appreciation—more “Microsoft‑like.”

— Base case: A powerful but cyclical super‑cycle. Geopolitics and competition pressure margins and share, slowing growth and compressing P/E toward 20–30x, with more volatility and cyclicality.

— Bear case: Bubble deflates. AI ROI disappoints, geopolitical headwinds worsen, and China exposure erodes. Earnings underwhelm, P/E contracts sharply, and the stock retraces materially.

Practical takeaways for individual investors

Section titled “Practical takeaways for individual investors”

For a high‑valuation, high‑volatility leader like NVIDIA, investing is ultimately a judgment on long‑term fundamentals—not short‑term price moves. Keep an eye on:

  • Data Center growth: Is the core engine sustaining robust y/y expansion?
  • Gross margin: Can GM hold ~70%+, signaling pricing power and platform moat?
  • Geopolitics: Track U.S.–China policy developments and revenue exposure.
  • Competitive dynamics: Watch AMD and custom silicon traction across hyperscalers.

Bottom line: NVIDIA is not a simple “bubble.” Its premium valuation rests on formidable fundamentals and a vast market opportunity. But challenges are real. Whether it remains the AI era’s dominant platform over the next decade depends on staying technologically ahead while navigating geopolitics and intensifying competition—turning the P/E “story” into compounding earnings reality.

Note: This analysis is based on public information and is not investment advice. Markets involve risk; invest prudently.

item.title: Efficient AI Implementation for Business: Stop Building Demos, Start Building Working Systems
item.content:encoded:
Executives excited, technology teams frustrated, business units reluctant to adopt. This isn’t a technical problem—it’s an organizational problem. Whether AI implementation succeeds depends on whether the “executive-technology-business” triangular link can form a closed loop.

The following framework = practical playbook. You can directly copy and execute it.

Introduction | The Truth About the “Impossible Triangle”

Section titled “Introduction | The Truth About the “Impossible Triangle””

Over the past two years, from bots to agents, enthusiasm has been high, but projects have been slow to deliver. The reason is often not that models aren’t powerful enough, but that organizational collaboration isn’t aligned: executives want compelling narratives and expect ROI within three months, technology teams want multimodality + compliance + scalability, and business units only care about KPIs and conversion rates.

Real-world data also reminds us: enterprise-level ROI typically takes longer—don’t expect instant results. Forrester and frontline CIO retrospectives indicate that 18–24 months is more common; rushing for quick results often leads to “burning money without results.”

IBM-commissioned 2024/25 research also shows that less than half of enterprise AI projects are profitable in their first year, with most considering cost savings within three years as a reasonable expectation.

AI implementation isn’t a technology race—it’s organizational engineering. MVP, workflow restructuring, governance, and KPI tracking are all essential.

1. Organization First: Getting All Three Parties at the Same Table

Section titled “1. Organization First: Getting All Three Parties at the Same Table”

What should executives do?

  • Appoint a “top-level project” leader, with CEO/General Manager personally overseeing governance and cross-departmental coordination.
  • Define “three lists”: investment boundaries, risk red lines, and metrics to monitor within 90 days.

McKinsey’s global research shows that direct senior leadership responsibility for AI governance and tracking clear KPIs correlate significantly with higher actual profit improvements.

What should technology teams do?

  • Don’t showcase “tool exhibitions”—build “closed-loop toolchains”: Data → RAG/Agent → Analytics → Gradual Rollout → A/B Testing.
  • Integrate compliance and explainability into the pipeline, with data lineage/audit available on demand.

What should business units do?

  • Business objectives must be quantifiable and directly influenced by AI: AHT, FCR, conversion rates, processing time, person-days saved.
  • Business team members participate in prompt co-creation. Latest research emphasizes: prompt quality is as important as the model itself.

2. 90-Day Minimum Closed-Loop Strategy (Directly Executable)

Section titled “2. 90-Day Minimum Closed-Loop Strategy (Directly Executable)”

Day 0–7 | Choose Scenario

  • Select only one, prioritizing “text-intensive, standardized processes, high-volume and measurable” workflows: customer service responses, knowledge retrieval, email/contract drafting, ticket classification.
  • Establish baseline: e.g., customer service AHT, first-call resolution rate, NPS.

Day 8–21 | Build Foundation

  • Data cleaning + permission governance + RAG indexing, first organize “what can be queried” cleanly.
  • Set three types of tracking: quality (accuracy/recall), efficiency (duration/concurrency), effectiveness (conversion/savings).

Day 22–45 | Build MVP

  • Squad structure: Business PO + Tech TL + Data Governance + Legal/Compliance + AI Ops.
  • Business and technology co-write system prompts and few-shot examples, iterate twice weekly.
  • Deploy shadow mode: AI provides suggestions, humans execute.

Day 46–60 | A/B Testing

  • Split 20–30% traffic for comparison, monitor three metrics: AHT, first-call resolution rate, satisfaction.
  • Academic randomized experiments in customer service scenarios show: agents using generative AI achieve 14–15% productivity improvement per person, with greater improvement for newcomers. Design your metric system based on this replication.

Day 61–90 | Gradual Scaling

  • Upon reaching thresholds, move to semi-automation: AI answers routine questions first, humans handle complex issues.
  • Establish change and rollback mechanisms, automatically downgrade when metrics fall below thresholds.

OECD’s 2025 assessment emphasizes: to capture productivity dividends, organization, processes, and strategies must adjust for AI, not just “switching models.”

Realistic Expectations

  • Cost recovery depends on project complexity, 6–24 months is reasonable; over-pursuing “quarterly ROI” is likely counterproductive.

3. Six “Quick-Win” Scenario Categories (with KPIs)

Section titled “3. Six “Quick-Win” Scenario Categories (with KPIs)”
  1. Customer Service Support/Knowledge Retrieval
  • KPIs: AHT↓, first-call resolution rate↑, NPS↑;
  • Key elements: High-frequency Q&A knowledge base + RAG, process templates, quality spot-checks;
  • Supporting evidence: significant productivity improvement, greater benefits for newcomers.
  1. Sales Email/Proposal Drafting
  • KPIs: Reach rate/response rate/appointment rate;
  • Key elements: CRM data → personalized insights → generate draft → human refinement.
  1. Contract/Legal Document Drafts
  • KPIs: Drafting time, per-person processing volume, review round-trips;
  • Key elements: Clause library + prompt templates + approval watermarks;
  • Legal teams no longer just act as “brakes,” but are integrated into the framework as “guardrails”.
  1. Financial Reconciliation/Receipt Extraction
  • KPIs: Verification accuracy, processing time, anomaly recall;
  • Key elements: Structured extraction + rule validation + anomaly ticketing.
  1. Supply Chain/Production Planning Q&A
  • KPIs: Plan variance, stockout rate, decision latency;
  • Key elements: Constraint-based Q&A + explainable reasoning → human approval.
  • Research indicates LLMs help with decision-making in medium to long-term forecasting.
  1. Internal Knowledge Portal
  • KPIs: Search time, repeat question rate, satisfaction;
  • Key elements: Permission tiering, hotspot iteration, feedback-retraining closed loop.

4. Governance and Costs: Don’t Let “Saving People” Become “Burning Cloud”

Section titled “4. Governance and Costs: Don’t Let “Saving People” Become “Burning Cloud””
  • Cost tracking trio: Inference fees, vector retrieval/bandwidth, annotation and evaluation.
  • Computing power throttling: Small models + caching + retrieval pruning; gradual traffic and peak-valley scheduling.
  • Quality/risk dual dashboard: Accuracy rate, hallucination rate, privacy/copyright/IP incidents.
  • Industry observation: enterprises generally felt “difficult returns” in 2024, turning toward “focusing on high-value use cases + cost control” in 2025.

5. Replicable Organizational Mechanism (This Template)

Section titled “5. Replicable Organizational Mechanism (This Template)”
  • Exec Sponsor (Executive): Decision maker, resource guarantor, route interference blocker;
  • AI PMO/Transformation Office: Rhythm, milestones, risk list, experience reuse;
  • Business PO: KPI setting, prompt co-creation, acceptance;
  • Tech TL: Architecture, performance, deployment/rollback;
  • Data Governance: Permissions/lineage/audit/tracking;
  • Legal/Compliance: AI Act/privacy/copyright compliance;
  • AI Ops: Monitoring, evaluation, model switching.

Research shows: tracking KPIs, phased roadmaps, dedicated teams correlate significantly with actual EBIT improvement.

6. Two “Real Case” Insights

Section titled “6. Two “Real Case” Insights”
  • Customer Service/Agent Assistant: Academic randomized experiments prove 14–15% productivity improvement, especially for newcomers; you can replicate your metric design accordingly.
  • KPMG Tax Agent (TaxBot): Under compliance premises, uses RAG to aggregate tax law and internal knowledge, generating 25-page recommendation drafts for significant efficiency gains, but operational authority is limited to certified tax professionals, keeping risks controlled.

7. Ten Pitfall Avoidance Checklist (Project Retrospective Must-Check)

Section titled “7. Ten Pitfall Avoidance Checklist (Project Retrospective Must-Check)”
  1. Replacing scenarios with demos → ❌; Using single KPI instead of price tags → ✅
  2. Only discussing models without data → ❌; Data/permissions first → ✅
  3. No tracking, no evaluation → ❌; A/B + shadow mode → ✅
  4. Pursuing comprehensive solutions → ❌; Single-point closed loop → ✅
  5. “Random” annotation → ❌; Quality inspection task system → ✅
  6. Writing prompts for yourself → ❌; Write as product documentation → ✅ (Prompt quality = half the product)
  7. Legal as afterthought → ❌; Legal in parallel → ✅
  8. Budget guesswork → ❌; Milestone-based funding → ✅
  9. Only using “generic Copilots” → ❌; Deep vertical process focus → ✅
  10. Only discussing quarterly ROI → ❌; 6–24 month payback period → ✅

Conclusion | Find the Right “Bridge Person,” and the Triangle Won’t Be Difficult

Section titled “Conclusion | Find the Right “Bridge Person,” and the Triangle Won’t Be Difficult”

The key to AI implementation is that person who can “translate” between executives, technology, and business. With this bridge, the minimum closed loop can function, and the flywheel of data-prompts-evaluation-gradual rollout can start spinning. Don’t compete on demos, compete on closed loops. This is the scarcest competitive advantage in companies in 2025.

Still hesitating about ROI? Enterprise surveys show: most companies today are still on the journey, but with proper structure/processes/governance, value starts landing.

Discussion Questions

Section titled “Discussion Questions”
  • In your company’s current “power triangle”, who’s pushing, who’s dragging, who’s coasting?
  • For the next 90-day minimum scenario, where would you choose? Why?

item.title: Claude Code Best Practices: The Prototyping Method
item.content:encoded:
First, use Claude Code to quickly “get a prototype working” to refine the requirements; then, return to engineering design and implementation to ensure quality and stability. Efficiency and quality, we want both.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

The hardest part of product development isn’t writing code. It’s clearly defining “what needs to be built.”

That’s why I recommend this two-stage approach: Build a prototype in the first version, and handle the engineering seriously in the second. Claude Code is well-suited for this strategy: it works alongside you in the terminal, handling the grunt work first, allowing you to refine it later.

The 2 Stages of the Prototyping Method

Section titled “The 2 Stages of the Prototyping Method”

Stage 1: Prototype Only, Aim for “It Works”

Section titled “Stage 1: Prototype Only, Aim for “It Works””
  • Goal: Get the feature running to make the requirements tangible.
  • Ignore: Design, performance, security, code quality.
  • Method: Use throwaway code, letting the AI take the lead to quickly explore feasible paths (similar to “Spike/Throwaway Prototyping”).

Why this approach? Because many ambiguities are only exposed when the code is running. Screenshots, GIFs, and clickable prototypes are far more useful than a ten-page requirements document.

Claude Code’s advantages in this stage:

  • Directly read, modify, and run code within your local project—conversation becomes action.
  • Frequent actions can be turned into Slash Commands for one-click reuse, like “start backend + mock data + run locally.”

A word of caution: If you’re using a personal subscription, Anthropic recently introduced an opt-in mechanism for data training that includes Claude Code sessions. Check your privacy settings before prototyping company projects.

Stage 2: Redesign and Engineer Seriously

Section titled “Stage 2: Redesign and Engineer Seriously”
  • Trigger: Requirements are mostly finalized, and the scope is stable.
  • Deliverables: Database schema, API contracts, state management, module boundaries, testing strategy, etc.
  • Pace: Human-led, AI-assisted. You set the design anchors, and the AI builds according to the plan.

How to use Claude Code in this stage:

  • Let it scaffold the project, add boilerplate, and write tests based on your design.
  • @claude in PRs/Issues to automatically create PRs and fix minor issues (via GitHub Actions integration).
  • Write engineering conventions into a CLAUDE.md file or Slash Commands to ensure the AI follows project rules.

Security/Non-Functional Advice: Treat security, performance, and maintainability as “Technical Enablers” and progressively incorporate them into your Definition of Done (DoD) during the second stage. Conduct Spikes for validation when necessary.

When Can You Skip the Prototype?

Section titled “When Can You Skip the Prototype?”
  • The requirements have already been validated (e.g., redoing an old feature, a clear competitor to model after).
  • The primary risk is in the engineering implementation, not the product definition. In this case, you can proceed directly to Stage 2: Design and Implementation, with Claude Code acting as a scaffolding and execution tool.

Field Guide: My Recommended Uses in Daily Development

Section titled “Field Guide: My Recommended Uses in Daily Development”

Here are practical checklists for prototyping to engineering across four common scenarios.

Example A: Growth Experiment Landing Page (Next.js)

Section titled “Example A: Growth Experiment Landing Page (Next.js)”

Prototype Version (Half a day)

  • Have Claude Code generate a minimal page, tracking events, and a form that submits to /api/echo.
  • Get it running with mock data and simple A/B test parameters.

Engineered Version

  • Design the routing and data models, and agree on event names for tracking.
  • Generate OpenAPI specs or protocol documents; write unit/contract tests; integrate the Claude Code Action in CI for automated checks and fixes.

Example B: Mini-Program / BLE Device Data Collection

Section titled “Example B: Mini-Program / BLE Device Data Collection”

Prototype Version

  • Prioritize getting the scan → connect → read → local cache flow working, ignoring exception handling.
  • Use Slash Commands to quickly reuse build and on-device debugging commands.

Engineered Version

  • Define the state machine (connected/disconnected/reconnecting/timeout).
  • Design the offline synchronization protocol and replay strategy; add boundary tests.
  • Create a /test-ble-reconnect command for fault injection and recovery.

Example C: Internal Approval System (Rails/React)

Section titled “Example C: Internal Approval System (Rails/React)”

Prototype Version

  • Focus only on the core workflow: submit, route, approve/reject.
  • Use an in-memory store or SQLite; don’t implement permissions yet.

Engineered Version

  • Design the RBAC and audit log table structures; write migration scripts.
  • Add rate limiting, audit export, and SLO reporting; let Claude Code automatically fix minor issues and add tests in PRs.

Example D: Data Service (FastAPI + DuckDB)

Section titled “Example D: Data Service (FastAPI + DuckDB)”

Prototype Version

  • Start with three read-only APIs for different scenarios, returning static or semi-dynamic data.
  • Ignore caching and permissions to get the frontend unblocked.

Engineered Version

  • Define the pagination/sorting/filtering protocol and error codes; add authentication.
  • Add a caching layer and rate limiting; create a /bench-api command to run load tests against a baseline.

Claude Code’s “Metronome”

Section titled “Claude Code’s “Metronome””
  • Interactive terminal + command line allows for high-frequency iteration by chatting and modifying files.
  • Slash Commands solidify your “operational playbooks” for team sharing.
  • GitHub Actions bring @claude into PRs/Issues for automatic patching, PR generation, and enforcing project standards.

Together, these three features create a fast track from “idea → prototype → engineered product.”

Common Pitfalls and My Evasions

Section titled “Common Pitfalls and My Evasions”
  • Prototype drags on for too long: If requirements aren’t settled in 1-2 weeks, break it down into smaller stories; conduct a Spike summary if needed.
  • Prototype code accidentally shipped to production: Use branch isolation, directory prefixes like /proto-*, and CI checks to block it.
  • Unbounded second stage: Write an Engineering DoD (including security and performance), list non-functional items as Technical Enablers, and complete them sprint by sprint.
  • Privacy compliance: Prioritize enterprise/API channels for company projects; for personal subscriptions, always check data training opt-in settings.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Prototyping isn’t about being lazy; it’s about accelerating clarity. Engineering isn’t about being slow; it’s about reducing long-term costs.

With Claude Code, we can put these two activities in their proper place: AI leads the prototyping, humans lead the engineering. Take that hesitant requirement you have right now, and just get it running.

What do you think? Does your team get stuck more in the prototyping or engineering phase? Let’s discuss in the comments.

NVIDIA FY26 Q1–Q2 Earnings Synthesis

Section titled “NVIDIA FY26 Q1–Q2 Earnings Synthesis”

I. Executive Summary: Strong Rebound in Adversity, Strategy Continues to Deliver

Section titled “I. Executive Summary: Strong Rebound in Adversity, Strategy Continues to Deliver”

NVIDIA’s FY26 Q1 and Q2 earnings together illustrate how, amid a complex geopolitical backdrop, a company can rely on core technological advantages and disciplined financial management to navigate shocks while continuing to deliver on long‑term strategy. Q1 centered on near‑term financial impact from U.S. export controls, including sizeable H20‑related charges and expected revenue shortfalls. Q2 not only exceeded expectations on key financial metrics but, through its strong results, provided compelling validation for the strategic direction and fundamental resilience articulated in Q1.

Our analysis finds that the apparent slowdown in Q2 total revenue growth is not a sign of weaker demand but a function of a high base, coinciding with a powerful ramp in the next‑gen Blackwell platform’s capacity and demand. More importantly, the company successfully transformed the H20 issue from Q1’s financial “wound” into a case study in strategic risk management and derisking in Q2. The quarter affirmed robust demand for the core growth engine (Blackwell), continued gross‑margin optimization, and management’s high confidence in future cash flows as evidenced by large‑scale capital returns.

II. Financial Performance: Strength Behind the Numbers and Structural Shifts

Section titled “II. Financial Performance: Strength Behind the Numbers and Structural Shifts”

Overview: A Beat, With Growth Moderation in Q2

Section titled “Overview: A Beat, With Growth Moderation in Q2”

In FY26 Q2, NVIDIA delivered standout results. Total revenue reached $46.743B, beating the prior $45.0B outlook by roughly $1.7B. Revenue grew 6% q/q and surged 56% y/y. GAAP net income climbed from $18.775B in Q1 to $26.422B, up 41% q/q and 59% y/y.

While impressive, Q2’s 56% y/y growth moderates versus Q1’s 69%. Some media framed this as the slowest quarterly growth since mid‑2023. Without context, that reading is incomplete. A 56% y/y increase is exceptional in any industry; the “slowdown” primarily reflects a rising comparison base—the natural consequence of sustained hyper‑growth—not weakening demand.

Despite the top‑line beat, NVIDIA’s stock dipped slightly post‑print—signaling an “expectations trap.” Street models for data center were ambitious; while the segment posted $41.1B, it trailed the highest estimates by ~$(0.24)B. The market’s lens has moved beyond total revenue to the AI data center core. Even small deviations can trigger outsized reactions—part of the unique pressure borne by the global AI bellwether.

Segment Deep Dive

Section titled “Segment Deep Dive”

Comparing segment results across the two quarters highlights structural shifts driving growth.

  • Data Center: Still the dominant engine. Q1 revenue was $39.1B (+73% y/y); Q2 rose to $41.1B (+56% y/y). Data center remained ~88% of total revenue, underscoring its centrality.

  • Gaming: NVIDIA’s legacy core also rebounded strongly in Q2, with revenue of $4.3B (+14% q/q, +49% y/y). The key driver was the Blackwell‑powered NVIDIA GeForce RTX 5060, which quickly became the fastest‑ramping x60‑class GPU in company history—evidence that beyond AI chips, traditional franchises retain substantial vitality.

  • Professional Visualization and Automotive: Smaller in scale but solid. ProViz climbed from $509M in Q1 to $601M in Q2 (+18% q/q). Automotive rose from $567M to $586M (+69% y/y). These trends reflect NVIDIA’s expanding influence beyond core AI hardware via its full‑stack platforms (e.g., NVIDIA DRIVE AV, NVIDIA Omniverse) in vertical applications.

III. “Differences and Tensions” in Disclosures: Evolving Geopolitical Impact and Risk Management

Section titled “III. “Differences and Tensions” in Disclosures: Evolving Geopolitical Impact and Risk Management”

Q1: Direct Shock and Financial Cost

Section titled “Q1: Direct Shock and Financial Cost”

In FY26 Q1, NVIDIA faced its first direct financial hit since U.S.–China export controls tightened. The 10‑Q disclosed $4.5B of H20‑related charges due to demand decline, stemming mainly from excess inventory and purchase obligations. Additionally, ~$2.5B of H20 orders could not be delivered under policy constraints. These headwinds were visible in margins: GAAP GM dropped to 60.5%, non‑GAAP to 61.0%, both well below normalized levels. Q1 guided Q2 revenue to $45.0B and explicitly baked in ~$8.0B of H20 revenue impact from export controls.

Q2: Strategic Response and Derisking

Section titled “Q2: Strategic Response and Derisking”

At first glance, Q2 language seems to conflict with Q1. In reality, it reflects an evolution in geopolitical risk management and successful execution. Q2 stated “no H20 shipments to China customers.” That appears to extend Q1’s challenge. Yet management also disclosed ~$650M of H20 sales to non‑restricted customers outside China and the release of ~$180M in previously established inventory reserves.

Viewed together, this is not a data contradiction but a transition from “forced to absorb” to “actively managing.” The $4.5B in Q1 represented inventory and purchase obligations then seen as a heavy burden—potentially stranded assets. In Q2, NVIDIA found new channels and monetized part of what looked unmarketable, generating revenue and boosting gross margin by reversing a portion of reserves. This shows NVIDIA was not passively absorbing external shocks; it proactively adjusted supply chain and sales strategies to minimize damage and revitalize assets.

Separately, reports of a “15% revenue‑share arrangement” with the U.S. government were addressed. CFO Colette Kress said the agreement is not finalized and no rule has been published. Even so, the disclosure implies substantial behind‑the‑scenes negotiation. Importantly, Q3 outlook still assumes “no H20 shipments to China,” reflecting conservative forecasting—any such agreement would be treated as upside, not base case—avoiding secondary risk from policy volatility.

IV. How Q2 “Validated” Q1 Strategy: From Blueprint to Reality

Section titled “IV. How Q2 “Validated” Q1 Strategy: From Blueprint to Reality”

Data Center Long‑Term Strategy: The Rise of Blackwell

Section titled “Data Center Long‑Term Strategy: The Rise of Blackwell”

In Q1, CEO Jensen Huang articulated optimism for the next‑gen Blackwell platform—the “AI platform the world has been waiting for.” Then, it sounded like blueprint and vision. Q2 backed it with hard data.

Management indicated a ~17% q/q increase in Blackwell data center revenue in Q2. This is more than a number; it reflects core technical leadership and market position. Huang called Blackwell demand “extraordinary,” directly affirming the prior quarter’s outlook. The ramp and demand are effectively offsetting H20 export constraints, becoming a new driver of overall growth.

Financial Resilience and Shareholder Returns: From Target to Action

Section titled “Financial Resilience and Shareholder Returns: From Target to Action”

Alongside Q1’s disclosure of H20‑driven gross margin compression, NVIDIA set a clear goal: lift non‑GAAP GM to the “mid‑70% range” by year end. Q2 nearly perfectly validated that commitment.

Decomposing the data shows non‑GAAP GM reached 72.7% in Q2, up roughly 1 point from Q1’s 71.3% after excluding H20 impacts. Two factors drove the rebound: first, the $180M reserve release from H20 inventory provided a short‑term boost; second—and more important structurally—higher mix and shipments of next‑gen, higher‑margin products like Blackwell. This indicates margin volatility is largely tied to one‑off events (H20), while core profitability and long‑term optimization via higher value mix are intact and progressing.

On capital returns, Q1 reiterated ongoing buybacks and dividends. In Q2, this commitment intensified: the board authorized an additional $60B in share repurchases—an unprecedented signal of management’s confidence in fundamentals and future cash flows. It reinforced the financial moat and sent a strong constructive signal to the market.

V. Outlook and Risks: Challenges and Opportunities Ahead

Section titled “V. Outlook and Risks: Challenges and Opportunities Ahead”

Q3 guidance further cements growth momentum: revenue of $54.0B (±2%), about $7.3B above Q2’s actual, with GAAP and non‑GAAP GM guided to ~73.3% and ~73.5%. This outlook evidences an accelerating Blackwell ramp, sustained demand, and confidence in ongoing profitability improvements.

Risks remain. Geopolitical uncertainty tops the list; any change in export regimes could directly affect revenue. Competitive intensity from emerging AI silicon players (e.g., Groq) is rising. While NVIDIA retains clear leadership, it must continue to innovate to sustain its edge.

Opportunities are likewise substantial. Through continued expansion into AI, robotics, physical AI, and digital twins, NVIDIA is evolving from an AI hardware supplier into a full‑stack platform provider spanning multiple high‑growth arenas—laying a foundation for diversified growth.

VI. Conclusion: An AI Giant Advancing Through Headwinds

Section titled “VI. Conclusion: An AI Giant Advancing Through Headwinds”

Together, FY26 Q1 and Q2 form a coherent narrative of moving from financial pain to strategic counterpunch amidst external shocks. Q1 candidly revealed the direct cost of geopolitical risk; Q2 demonstrated managerial acumen and business resilience in action.

Q2 validated Q1’s core message: despite near‑term headwinds, NVIDIA’s long‑term growth engine—centered on Blackwell in data centers—remains powerful. Fundamentals and confidence in the future are solid. By converting challenge into opportunity via precise asset management and strong shipments of higher‑value products, NVIDIA achieved a notable rebound in financial metrics while signaling continued command and leadership in a complex environment. The company is steadily evolving from an AI chip maker into a full‑stack computing leader across AI, robotics, and the future of immersive platforms.

item.title: Q2 2025 Earnings Analysis: Companies With Standout Results in the AI Wave
item.content:encoded:
Earnings season is more than a string of numbers; it’s a contest between corporate strategy and market sentiment—and the best window into the broader economy and individual companies. A “strong earnings report” isn’t only about revenue or profit topping expectations; it should include a few core elements:

  • Degree of outperformance: The extent to which core financial metrics (revenue, EPS) beat market expectations.
  • Quality of growth: Whether growth is driven by sustainable core businesses rather than one-time factors.
  • Profitability and efficiency: Whether margins and cash flow improve as the company scales.
  • Forward guidance and management confidence: Upward guidance is usually the strongest signal of confidence.
  • Strategic execution: Whether the data validates a company’s long-term strategy.

We will analyze 10 companies riding the AI wave, unpacking the logic and business realities behind the numbers.

I. Company-by-Company: Deep Dive into 12 Companies’ Q2 2025 Earnings

Section titled “I. Company-by-Company: Deep Dive into 12 Companies’ Q2 2025 Earnings”

This section provides detailed financial and strategic analysis for each company, embedding all relevant research for fact-checking and critical evaluation.

1.1 Palantir (PLTR): A Successful Pivot from Government Services to a Commercial Engine

Section titled “1.1 Palantir (PLTR): A Successful Pivot from Government Services to a Commercial Engine”

Palantir’s Q2 results were a clear standout this quarter. Revenue reached $1.004B, far above market expectations of $940M, up 48% year over year. Even more notable was the leap in profitability: GAAP net income came in at $327M and adjusted EPS at $0.16, beating the $0.139 consensus.

The core driver behind these eye-catching figures was explosive growth in its U.S. commercial segment, where revenue grew 93% YoY and 20% QoQ—now the company’s strongest growth engine. This validates Palantir’s pivot from historical reliance on government contracts to a more scalable commercial model. Commercial traction means stickier, more predictable revenue and long-term strategic partnerships, reflected in a total contract value (TCV) of $2.27B added in the quarter, up 140% YoY.

Still, beneath the headline numbers are risks that merit sober analysis. While government revenue grew a steady 36%, multiple sources indicate the U.S. Department of Defense has begun awarding contracts—potentially totaling up to $200M—to emerging competitors like OpenAI and Anthropic. This suggests government AI procurement is shifting from a single-vendor model to a more diversified approach. It may not immediately dent Palantir’s results, but it poses medium- to long-term challenges to the stability of its government revenue.

Looking ahead, management displayed strong confidence, raising Q3 revenue guidance (up 50% YoY) and full-year revenue guidance (up 45% YoY). This conviction is one of the most commendable aspects of the report. However, a trailing P/E of 663x and a forward P/E of 252x indicate the market has priced in much of this high growth. Such valuation demands continued outperformance to sustain.

1.2 Microsoft (MSFT): The Utility Giant of the AI Era

Section titled “1.2 Microsoft (MSFT): The Utility Giant of the AI Era”

Microsoft’s results were equally impressive. Calendar Q2 (fiscal Q4) revenue reached $76.4B, up 18% YoY, beating the 13.9% consensus. Diluted EPS was $3.65, up 24% YoY, topping the $3.35 estimate.

The headline is the comprehensive win of its “Cloud + AI” strategy. Azure—the company’s growth engine—grew revenue 39% YoY. This isn’t just a financial number; it signals a fundamental shift in Microsoft’s business model. The company is no longer just a software vendor; it’s becoming the indispensable provider of AI compute and data infrastructure for enterprises worldwide. To meet massive AI demand, Microsoft plans to invest $80B in data centers in fiscal 2025. This capex is not mere expense—it’s a strategic bet on the future, aiming to resolve supply constraints and cement leadership in the AI era.

Strategically, this report shows Microsoft has successfully transformed from a traditional software giant into a company with “AI-infrastructure-as-utility” characteristics. By embedding itself in the digital arteries of the global economy, Microsoft continues to earn market trust and premium valuation. Management’s outlook remains highly optimistic, projecting that Intelligent Cloud revenue will continue to grow rapidly in fiscal Q1 2026, up an estimated 37%.

1.3 Astera Labs (ALAB): The “Picks-and-Shovels” Player—And Its Risks

Section titled “1.3 Astera Labs (ALAB): The “Picks-and-Shovels” Player—And Its Risks”

Astera Labs delivered “stunning” figures. Revenue hit $191.9M, up 150% YoY and 20% QoQ. More importantly, the company achieved GAAP operating income of $39.8M and GAAP net income of $51.2M for the first time—marking a shift from hypergrowth to healthy profitability. As a supplier of data center interconnect chips, Astera Labs is directly benefiting from accelerated capex by hyperscalers on AI compute infrastructure.

However, we must recognize structural vulnerabilities beneath the polish. Multiple sources emphasize the biggest risk is customer concentration—the business depends heavily on “a small number of large hyperscaler customers.” While growth is currently surging, large customers seek to avoid over-reliance on any single supplier. Changes in their procurement strategies—or internal development of substitutes—could be a material threat. Perfect numbers notwithstanding, this oligopoly-dependence risk deserves investor attention.

1.4 Meta (META): Using the Ad Empire’s Cash Flow to Bet on AI’s Future

Section titled “1.4 Meta (META): Using the Ad Empire’s Cash Flow to Bet on AI’s Future”

Meta’s Q2 results show its core ad business remains vibrant under AI’s influence. Revenue was $47.52B, up 22% YoY; EPS came in at $7.14, up 38% YoY. Growth was driven by both ad impressions and average price—powered by continued improvements in AI targeting and recommendations.

The most striking aspect isn’t the strength of the core business, but the strategy the report reveals. Meta explicitly divides itself into two segments: the $47.146B “Family of Apps” (the cash cow) and the $370M “Reality Labs.” Family of Apps generates ample cash flow to fund massive investments in AI and the metaverse. Capex is projected at $66–72B in 2025, primarily for AI infrastructure. Strategically, such investment is risky—but necessary to win the future. The perfection here is that the cash cow remains robust, granting management greater strategic freedom to pursue an ambitious vision.

1.5 Nebius AI (NBIS): A Dark Horse in AI Infrastructure

Section titled “1.5 Nebius AI (NBIS): A Dark Horse in AI Infrastructure”

Nebius AI, a fast-rising player in AI infrastructure, delivered jaw-dropping Q2 results. Revenue reached $105.1M, surging 625% YoY and 106% QoQ. Its core business also achieved positive adjusted EBITDA ahead of schedule—evidence of a healthy, efficient model.

Nebius’s success is no accident. Offering “full-stack” services from GPU compute and cloud platform to developer tools, its vertical integration allows it to respond quickly to soaring AI compute demand. The company is actively securing over 1GW of power supply to support future data center expansion—signaling very aggressive growth expectations. Notably, Nebius Group N.V. was formerly Yandex N.V., renamed in August 2024—a key context for understanding its technological base and business model.

1.6 Robinhood (HOOD): From Hype App to Financial Platform Reborn

Section titled “1.6 Robinhood (HOOD): From Hype App to Financial Platform Reborn”

Robinhood’s Q2 report shows it is no longer a “meme stock” trading app riding short-term sentiment. Revenue reached $989M, up 45% YoY; net income was $386M, up 105% YoY.

These numbers reflect a successful model shift. The company is no longer dependent on a single source of trading income. Trading revenue (options, crypto, equities) grew 65% YoY, while net interest income grew a steady 25%. Paid subscribers (Robinhood Gold) rose 76% to 3.5M, and assets under management (AUM) reached $279B, up 99% YoY. This all points to a transition toward a diversified, sustainable, full-spectrum financial services platform.

What makes this report “perfect” is that it proves the company is evolving from a “tool” to a “platform.” The strategy stems from understanding user needs: younger investors don’t just want a simple trading tool; they want a one-stop platform for end-to-end financial needs.

1.7 Iren (IREN): A Bold Strategic Pivot and Hypergrowth

Section titled “1.7 Iren (IREN): A Bold Strategic Pivot and Hypergrowth”

Iren’s results this quarter (fiscal Q4) are dramatic. Despite some timeline confusion (fiscal Q2 vs. Q4), the latest data (fiscal Q4, published Aug 2025) shows revenue of $187.3M, up 228% YoY, and net income of $176.9M—successfully turning profitable.

The perfection here stems from a bold and successful strategic pivot. No longer confined to Bitcoin mining, Iren has leveraged its advantages in power and infrastructure to expand into high-growth AI data centers. Becoming an NVIDIA “preferred partner” and securing Blackwell GPUs provides robust technical and hardware support for rapid AI expansion. This pivot shifts Iren from a business tied to highly volatile Bitcoin pricing to one with more stable, durable demand. Strategically, both the legacy (mining) and new (AI data centers) businesses rely on the same core assets—power and large-scale data center infrastructure. The earnings data shows the company can reallocate these assets into AI compute services—a strategic redeployment of core resources.

1.8 SoFi (SOFI): A “Financial Services Flywheel” Perfectly Validated

Section titled “1.8 SoFi (SOFI): A “Financial Services Flywheel” Perfectly Validated”

SoFi delivered a near-perfect Q2. Revenue reached $855M, up 43% YoY. More importantly, it achieved GAAP profitability for the seventh consecutive quarter, with net income of $97.3M—up 459% YoY.

The highlight is the validation of its unique “Financial Services Productivity Loop” (FSPL) strategy. Members and products both grew 34% YoY. Notably, 35% of new products were activated by existing members—strong evidence of a “one-stop shop” model. By offering a full suite of financial products (deposits, loans, investing, etc.), SoFi is lifting ARPU and product penetration. A 72% surge in fee-based revenue also improves revenue quality and reduces dependence on interest income. Management raised full-year 2025 guidance, signaling strong confidence.

1.9 Axon (AXON): A Gorgeous Shift from “Hardware Sales” to “SaaS Subscriptions”

Section titled “1.9 Axon (AXON): A Gorgeous Shift from “Hardware Sales” to “SaaS Subscriptions””

Axon’s earnings illustrate how to build a moat. Revenue reached $669M, up 33% YoY—its sixth consecutive quarter above 30% growth. The standout datapoints: ARR up 39% to $1.2B and a staggering $10.7B in future contracted backlog. That figure implies stable, predictable revenue over the next decade—rare and a key justification for premium valuation.

The data shows Axon’s real value doesn’t come from hardware like Tasers or cameras, but from the software ecosystem built around them—digital evidence management, VR training, and more. This “hardware as entry, software at the core” model creates lock-in: once law-enforcement customers join the ecosystem, switching costs are extremely high and subscription revenue becomes durable. Management raised 2025 revenue and adjusted EBITDA guidance, further validating strong execution.

1.10 TransMedics (TMDX): A Vertical “Full-Stack” Builder in MedTech

Section titled “1.10 TransMedics (TMDX): A Vertical “Full-Stack” Builder in MedTech”

TransMedics posted solid Q2 performance. Revenue reached $157.4M, up 38% YoY. Net income was $34.9M, up 186% YoY. Growth is driven by increased utilization of its proprietary Organ Care System (OCS) and the National OCS Program (NOP).

The report’s perfection stems from a unique “product + services” model. TransMedics doesn’t just sell a device; it offers an end-to-end solution spanning organ care to logistics. Services revenue rose 43.9% YoY, demonstrating the company’s ecosystem building (including its aviation fleet) can generate high-margin, sticky flywheel effects. By covering core needs “full-stack” (organ transport and care), TransMedics faces few direct competitors and creates long-term value. Management raised full-year 2025 revenue guidance, signaling strong conviction.

1.11 MongoDB (MDB): The Battle Between Growth and Profitability in Cloud Databases

Section titled “1.11 MongoDB (MDB): The Battle Between Growth and Profitability in Cloud Databases”

MongoDB beat on both revenue and non-GAAP earnings in Q2. Revenue reached $591.4M, up 23.7% YoY, above expectations. Adjusted EPS was $1.00, well ahead of the $0.67 estimate. Atlas, its cloud database service, was the core driver—74% of total revenue—growing 29% YoY.

However, despite strong non-GAAP metrics, the report shows a GAAP operating loss of $71.4M. Many observers also stress that achieving sustained GAAP net profitability remains a “long-term challenge.” Strategically, MongoDB sits in the eternal trade-off between growth and profitability, spending aggressively to capture the huge cloud database opportunity. Investors currently prioritize its potential in AI and cloud databases over near-term GAAP profitability. This strategy is rational—but it also means that if growth slows, scrutiny on profitability will intensify.

1.12 Shopify (SHOP): Steady Global Expansion of E-commerce Infrastructure

Section titled “1.12 Shopify (SHOP): Steady Global Expansion of E-commerce Infrastructure”

Shopify’s Q2 was steady and consistent. Revenue grew 31% YoY, and free-cash-flow margin has stayed in double digits for eight consecutive quarters—an extremely healthy financial profile. A notable detail is the success of its globalization strategy: GMV growth accelerated across North America, Europe, and APAC, with Europe up as high as 42%. Shopify isn’t resting on North America; geographic diversification opens new growth while reducing single-market concentration risk.

The company emphasized that merchants from startups to global brands are choosing Shopify, indicating rising platform appeal across customer sizes. Looking to Q3, Shopify expects revenue to grow in the high-20s percent range YoY. This steady growth trajectory supports continued leadership in e-commerce and a broadly optimistic outlook.

II. The Leaderboard: Q2 2025’s “Perfect Ten” Earnings

Section titled “II. The Leaderboard: Q2 2025’s “Perfect Ten” Earnings”

Based on the above deep-dive analysis—and our criteria for a “perfect earnings report” (outperformance, growth quality, profitability, guidance, and execution)—we score 12 companies and select the top 10.

3.1 Macro Themes: Signals from Q2 Earnings Season

Section titled “3.1 Macro Themes: Signals from Q2 Earnings Season”

The defining theme of the quarter is “AI”—now a tangible driver of revenue and profit rather than mere concept. Whether Palantir, Microsoft, Astera Labs, or Iren, surging results are inseparable from AI infrastructure build-out and applications. This suggests a major upgrade underway in the foundations of the digital economy, and those at the core of the AI supply chain are enjoying unprecedented growth dividends.

Additionally, vertical “full-stack services” are becoming the new moat. Companies like Axon, TransMedics, and SoFi don’t just sell products—they lock in customers by offering complete solutions. Once inside the ecosystem, customers face high switching costs and generate durable, predictable revenue—creating formidable competitive barriers.

3.2 Guidance for Individual Investors

Section titled “3.2 Guidance for Individual Investors”

When reading this leaderboard, look beyond the surface numbers and grasp the underlying business logic:

  • Watch valuation—but focus more on growth quality: Sky-high multiples aren’t inherently good or bad. Analyze whether growth drivers are sustainable and whether the business model is defensible. High-quality, moated growth can be more valuable than a low-multiple, stagnating business.
  • Monitor strategic pivots: Companies that dare to and successfully execute strategic shifts (e.g., PLTR, HOOD, IREN) often deliver outsized returns by changing market perception and unlocking new growth.
  • Investing isn’t a one-off trade—it’s a long-term partnership: Earnings season reveals a company’s “character.” Watch how management faces challenges and allocates capital. If you align with the long-term vision, short-term price swings need not shake your conviction.
